_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Formosa Plastics Industrial Park, located on F-M 1593 in Point Comfort, Texas, is operated by Formosa Plastics Corporation, Texas (FPC-TX). FPC-TX is a vertically integrated organization. It consists of eleven "covered process" operations, and four support organizations. The facility is located in the city of Point Comfort, Calhoun County, Texas. The facility currently employs approximately 1600 employees.



The "Covered Processes" are:

Olefins 1

Olefins 2

Polypropylene 1

Polypropylene 2

High Density Polypropylene 1

High Density Polypropylene 2

Linear Low Density Polyethylene

Polyvinyl Chloride

Vinyl Chloride Monomer

Ethylene Glycol

Marine Traffic

Inland Traffic

Specialty PVC

Utilities

Inventory Control

Pet-Coke/Coal Energy Generating Facility (CFB)

Chlor-Alkali



The Risk Management Plan (RMP) was prepared by the Corporate Director of Security & Risk Management

Each operating unit has appointed one individual as the person responsible for implementation of the RMP in that Unit. The Environmental, Health and Safety Department, through the Emergency Response Coordinator, oversee, provide guidance, and audit the RMP activities of the operating units.



Compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119: On May 26, 1992, OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule went into effect. FPC-TX is covered under this rule. The PSM rule consists of fourteen (14) elements. The facility has developed and implemented the fourteen elements of this rule.



COVERED PROCESS - BRIEF DESCRIPTION



Olefins 1 & 2



Combined, Olefins 1 and Olefins 2 have twenty-two pyrolysis furnaces used to crack a range of feedstock consisting of propane (3), natural gas liquids (NGL) (2), naphtha (4), and an ethane/propane mixture (1). The resulting products are ethylene (7), propylene (8), a mixed C4 product (9), pyrolysis gasoline (10), and pyrolysis fuel oil (11). The furnaces are fired with fuel gas (5).  The materials listed as flammable mixtures containing 1, 3 butadiene

, 1- butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, 3-methyl-1-butene, butane, vinyl acetylene, isopentane, and pentane.

Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Polypropylene 1



The Polypropylene I Unit utilizes BASF gas-phase reactor technology to produce polypropylene resin using propylene supplied from the Olefins Plant. Each production line has an independent Polymerization Area, Extrusion Area and Silo Area. Common to all production lines are the Raw Material Tank Farm, Purification Area, and Catalyst Preparation Area.



All raw materials, propylene, hydrogen, nitrogen, ethylene, propylene oxide, and hexane are purified in molecular sieve columns to remove carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and moisture. Pellets from the drier are sent to the Pellet Blending Silos for mixing to develop a homogeneous product. From the blending silos, the pellets are sent to the Pellet Product Silos for temporary storage. The PP pellets (L) are then loaded into railcars and sent to customers. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant and chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Polypropylene 2



The Polypropylene II Unit utilizes Chisso/Amoco technology to produce polypropylene resin using propylene

supplied from the Olefins Plant. The Polypropylene II Unit has two independent production lines, Train No. 1 and Train No. 2. Each production line has an independent Polymerization Area, Extrusion Area and Silo Area.

Common to both production lines are the Raw Material Tank Farm, Purification Area, and Catalyst Preparation Area.



All raw materials, hydrogen, nitrogen, ethylene, and hexane are purified in molecular sieve columns to remove carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and moisture. Pellets from the drier are sent to the Pellet Blending Silos for mixing to develop a homogeneous product. From the blending silos, the pellets are sent to the Pellet Product Silos for temporary storage. The PP pellets (L) are then loaded into railcars and sent to customers.

Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



High Density Polypropylene 1



The HDPE I plant is composed of the following sections: Catalyst Preparation, Ethylene Purification, Polymerization, Hexane Removal and Powder Drying, Extrusion, and Hexane Recovery and Refining. Ethylene, hydrogen, 1-butene, and hexane are fed into the reactor along with the catalyst and co-catalyst (titanium tetrachloride).



The polymerization process is a slurry process with hexane as the carrier solvent. After the polymerization step, the polyethylene slurry is sent first to the stripping section to recover hexane and then to the drying section. The dry polyethylene powder is transferred to the pelletizing section. The powder, mixed with additives and stabilizers, is then injected into the extruder. The resulting stabilized polyethylene melt is then fed to an underwater pelletizer and cut into small pellets. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



High Density Polyethylene 2



In the HDPE II Plant, polymerization occurs in iso-butane slurry using high activity proprietary catalyst in a loop reactor. The HDPE II Plant has the capability of producing different grades of products for various applications by customers. The HDPE II Plant is broken down into the following sections: Catalyst Preparation and Activation, Feed Preparation, Polymerization, Gas Recovery, Extrusion / Blending & Storage / Rail Car Loading.



The polymerization process reaction is continuous and occurs in a slurry phase with iso-butane as the carrier solvent. The slurry is directed to the High Pressure Flash Chamber where gases and light hydrocarbons are volatilized and exit through the top of the chamber. Ultimately the polymer is cut into pellets and then transferred to blending silos before being loaded for product shipping. 



Linear Low Density Polyethylene



The LLDPE Plant is designed to produce Linear Low Density Polyethylene using two parallel reactor lines. The

process employs a gas phase fluidized bed reactor in which ethylene and co-monomers are polymerized using a proprietary catalyst. Ethylene, hydrogen, and a co-monomer are reacted with injected pre-polymer powder in a fluidized bed reactor to produce LLDPE. This product is continuously withdrawn via a lateral withdrawal system for degassing and downstream process. The virgin powder is received and blended with additives for extrusion and pelletization. The product pellets are then pneumatically transferred to the product storage area.  1-Butene is used as monomer and titanium tetrachloride is a co-catalyst for reaction.  Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.



Polyvinyl Chloride



The PVC process is suspension polymerization. The general overall process involves the suspension of liquid vinyl chloride monomer in a continuous water phase. The sole function of the water diluent is to facilitate heat removal from the polymerization reaction. The reaction is initiated most commonly with organic peroxide soluble in the monomer phase. PVC slurry is centrifuged and then dried. The clean dry PVC is stored in silos, prior to being sold by railcar, tank truck, one ton bags, and 25 kg bags.



Vinyl Chloride Monomer



EDC is formed by oxychlorination of ethylene. Four oxychlorination trains are used to combine ethylene, hydrogen chloride, and oxygen to form ethylene dichloride. Purified EDC (10) is thermally cracked into VCM and HCl in the EDC Crackers. The VCM produced in the furnaces is purified, washed, dried, and sent to the Polyvinyl Chloride department for conversion to PVC. HCl (6) is also purified to meet the quality required as the raw material for the oxychlorination section. EDC is recycled back to the process. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Ethylene Glycol



The Ethylene Glycol plant produces monoethylene glycol, diethylene glyco, and triethylene glycol. The glycols are produced in two major steps. Oxygen from th

e Air Separation Plant (ASP) is reacted with ethylene from the Olefins Plant to form ethylene oxide (EO). EO is produced in the Scientific Design licensed glycol reaction and scrubbing section utilizing Mitsubishi reactors. This safe process begins with only 10 percent EO in a hydrolysis process to produce EG. There is no storage of EO on the site. If the EG unit is not running, the EO unit is shut down. The glycol is distilled into MEG, DEG, and TEG products. All process vents, except for the carbon dioxide regeneration vent, are directed to a furnace. Flammable mixture of ethylene and ethane is used in the process. Methane is used as a carrier during reaction. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Specialty PVC



Specialty Poly-Vinyl Chloride or SPVC involves the co-polymerization of VCM (Vinyl Chloride Monomer) and VAM (Vinyl Acetate Monomer). The process produces a fine, white powder that has many end product applications including: flooring, carpet backing, automobile underbody coatings, anti-fog applications, medical gloves, furniture, road cones, and many more. The production of SPVC involves three separate processes: (1) Emulsion Process; (2) Suspension-blending resin process and (3) Suspension-copolymer process. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Marine Traffic



Marine Traffic is charged with loading liquid products and unloading liquid feedstock to and from ships and barges. Products listed as flammable mixtures containing 1,3 butadiene, 1- butane, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, 3-methyl-1-butene, butane, vinyl acetylene,  isopentane, and pentane  are sent from the process units and Inland Traffic by pipeline and tank truck to the Marine Traffic Tank Farm for temporary storage until waterborne transportation can be arranged for FPC customers. Upon receiving shipping orders and the vessel to be loaded, Marine Traffic pumps the products from the Tank Farm to the Marine Terminal by pipeline into loading arm

s, and finally into the vessel. Transfer hoses may also be used.



At the Marine Terminal Tank Farm, raw materials off-loaded from barges and ships are stored prior to utilization by the plant and products from the plant are stored prior to loading into ships and barges. At the Marine Facility Dock Area, products are loaded onto barges and ships. The loading emissions are collected and burned in the Marine Facility Dock loading flare. The dock flare is designed to handle the vapors generated during the loading of hydrocarbon material. The marine facility has a vapor collection system to collect the loading emissions and route them to the dock flare. This system is vapor tight and ensures minimal emissions during loading.



Inland Traffic



Inland Traffic is charged with loading liquid products to railcars and trucks. Caustic is produced by the Ion

Exchange Membrane Plant and stored in tanks operated by the Traffic Department. Ethylene Dichloride

(EDC) is stored in tanks prior to being transferred to Marine Traffic or being sent to the Ethylene Glycol Plant.

Ethylene glycol's -- monoethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and triethylene glycol -- from the Ethylene Glycol Plant are stored in EG storage tanks prior to loading into railcars and trucks. Inland Traffic also receives propylene via railcars. The Propylene is stored in bullets and routed to either the Polypropylene Plant or Olefins Plant.



Utilities



The Utilities process provides utilities-water, electricity, steam and wastewater treatment for the entire FPC-TX site. For a defined RMP process - Utilities uses chlorine for water treatment.



Inventory Control 



Inventory Control serves as a central issuing and receiving entity for the entire FPC-TX site. For a defined

RMP process - Inventory Control serves as a central location for on-site delivery of full 1 Ton Chlorine cylinders and pick-up for empty 1 Ton Chlorine cylinders. Full chlorine cylinders are stored and issued to each process on an as

need basis.



Pet-Coke/Coal Energy Generating Facility 



Pet-Coke/Coal Energy Generating Facility (CFB) occupies 80.59 acres. CFB - circulating fluidized bed technology allows solid fuel to gain more time for combustion to achieve high efficiency. The overall output capacity is 300 Mega-Watts(MW) which is composed of two 150 MW generators., The main heating fuel is the petrochemical coke generated by refinery plants, which used to be treated as a waste and now used as a heating fuel source for power plants. The plant consist of eight major systems - 1)Water Treatment system, 2)Solid Fuel system, 3)Boiler and Turbine system, 4)Cooling Water System, 5)Electrical system, 6) SNCR, GSA and Waste Water System 7)Ash Handling System and the 8)DCS System. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Chlor-Alkali



The Chlor-Alkali process receives brine that is electrolytically separated into hydrogen, sodium hydroxide and chlorine. The chlorine is washed, dried and compressed. The end product is used in the production of 1, 2-dichloroethane process.





HAZARDS OF THE PROCESS



The hazards associated with the chemicals used in all the referenced "COVERED PROCESSES" requires the unit to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management rule (29 CFR 1910.119), NFPA 58 (Storage- and handling of liquefied petroleum gases), Spill Prevention Control & Countermeasure program, and other applicable Resource Conservation & Recovery Act rule (RCRA). The equipment installed in the units was designed based on either ASTM, ANSI, or ASME standards. Before starting the each unit, a process hazard analysis (PHA) as required by OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 was completed. The methodology used was the Hazards and Operability Study. Since the last PHA study, process parameters have been changed, and additional process controls, process detection systems and mitigation systems have been installed.



During the study, the PHA Team evaluated major hazards like, toxic gas rel

ease; fire; explosion; runaway reaction; polymerization; over pressurization and overfilling tanks, reactors, etc.; equipment failure; and loss of cooling, heating, electricity and instrument air.



Based on the hazards, the Team insured that there were adequate process controls like, vents; relief valves and rupture disks to insure that holding vessels do not fail in case of overfilling or over pressurization; check valves to insure that the chemicals do not flow back into equipment containing incompatible materials; flares in case of gas release; manual/ automatic shutoffs and excess flow device to prevent unwanted discharges; alarms and procedures for the operator to take action in case of a process upset; interlocks to insure that the system shuts down in case of an emergency; emergency air and power supply for equipment to keep functioning until the system can been shut down during utility failure; and process area detectors to warn the unit in advance of the impeding danger of a gas release. In case there was an incident, the Team also evaluated the mitigation systems like sprinkler and water deluge systems to either dilute or keep below the explosion point of a gas release; and dikes to insure that the release does not spread and contaminate the surrounding ground.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



5-year accidental release history: January, 2006 through December, 2011 was selected for the five-year accidental release history. There were no release accidents from a covered process involving a regulated substance that met the reporting requirements per the RMP regulation.



SUPPORT ORGANIZATIONS



Administration Department



Plans, organizes, directs, and controls the activities of the administrative services to carry out the administrative support operations at the company.



Inventory Control: Total commitment to providing service by ensuring that proper material stock levels are maintained, all materials received meet specifications, and right materials

of the best quality are delivered at the correct time.



Human Resources: Provides quality service to Operation Units in Human Resource management, i. e., securing consistency in the applications, policy, training, and providing timely answers to employee's questions, complaints, and concerns.



General Affairs: To provide reliable quality service in ground maintenance, office administration, and general affairs services.



Technical Department



Technical Department's responsibility is to provide laboratory-scale analyses and support to Operations for process control, environmental compliance, and product development. The personnel handle small amounts of hazardous gases and liquids in their daily functions.



Environmental, Health and Safety Department



The Environmental, Health and Safety Department (EHS) perform three major functions:

1) Policy writing

2) Training program development

3) Auditing of facility compliance



ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH AND SAFETY POLICY

"The company is committed to the protection of the environment, the safety and health of our employees and the community.



This is accomplished through the use of clear and well documented systems and procedures, proper training and qualification, high performance expectations, continual improvement in pollution prevention, minimization and recycling, as well as workplace hazard analysis and prevention.



Through the joint efforts of every employee, we shall maintain full compliance with all applicable environmental and safety laws and regulations, conserve natural resources, reduce wastes and keep our workplace free of health and safety hazards, for ourselves, for the community and for future generations."



Environmental is divided into two sections: Air Management and Water & Waste Management.



The Water and Waste Management Section is responsible to seek continual improvements in pollution prevention, waste minimization and recycling with regard to applicable water and solid hazardous

waste laws. Through the development of policies and procedures, training, and auditing, the Water and Waste Management section strives to assist the Operations units in meeting their Environmental Goals and maintain compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations.



The Air Management Section is responsible for policy development with regards to applicable air laws and regulations. Routine auditing of the facility ensures continued compliance and enhances all employees' environmental awareness. This section is also responsible for the operation of offsite air monitoring systems.

Health is divided into two sections: Industrial Hygiene and Medical.



The Industrial Hygiene Section is responsible for policy development and training in the areas of physical and chemical stressors. The section also audits these programs to help maintain compliance with regulations. 



The Medical Section provides a comprehensive physical examination program in accordance with OSHA standards. The staff utilizes the latest in medical equipment and technology to treat medical emergencies for company and contractor employees. This group provides assistance for non-occupational illnesses and injuries, coordinates Worker's Compensation claims, provides immunizations for hepatitis and tetanus vaccines and facilitates return to work for occupational and non-occupational cases.



Safety is divided into three sections: Safety, Emergency Response, and Security.



Safety is responsible for policy development as well as Facility auditing to check compliance with both Formosa policy and Federal safety standards.



The Emergency Response section is responsible for management and mitigation of emergencies (Fire, Haz-Mat, Rescue, and Medical) which may occur in the Facility. The Emergency Response section supervises and trains

Operations group personnel assigned to the Plant Emergency Response Team (ERT). Through routine auditing and inspections, the Emergency Response section chec

ks compliance with certain Formosa Plastics Corporation Environmental, Health and Safety procedures. The facility Emergency Response Team members can receive over 100 hours of training each every year; including 24 hours at the Texas A&M Industrial Fire School at College Station, Texas every year.



Security is responsible for policy development and daily oversight of facility physical security and compliance.



Maintenance Department



The FPC, Texas Maintenance Department is a multilevel Department established to maintain and increase equipment reliability and efficiency. Following are brief descriptions of the Maintenance Departments and their inter-relationships within this Facility.

Central Maintenance



Central Maintenance includes overall maintenance management and staff, maintenance discipline management, maintenance shop, maintenance service group, predictive maintenance, civil maintenance, and DCS and Analyzer Maintenance.



Maintenance Management (A. V P)



Responsible for overall Maintenance Department functions. The Maintenance A. V. P. is the primary contact point between Maintenance and Operations Management and the General Manager and Vice President of Operations.



Maintenance Shop



Provides machine shop, rotating equipment support, fabrication services, garage, fuel service, hydro blasting, vacuum truck service, valve repairs and other maintenance services for both Operations and the other maintenance departments.  The Maintenance shop also serves as a paper and used oil recycling collection point for the Facility.



Maintenance Service Group



Provides welding services, rotating equipment support, fabrication and small project services, garage, hydro blasting, vacuum truck service, and other maintenance services for both operations and other maintenance departments.



Civil Maintenance



Provides civil maintenance support to all Departments. In addition, they are responsible for railcar and rail repair.



Predictive Maintenance



P

redictive Maintenance provides a computerized corrosion/erosion program on predetermined intervals for the Facility to ensure equipment integrity is maintained. Additional services provided include Vibration analysis, various non-destructive testing services, remote visual inspection, alloy verification, Freon leak survey, oil analysis, tank settlement monitoring, visual inspections, gas leak testing, and other predictive maintenance services as requested.



Instrument Maintenance Analyzer/DCS Department



This Instrument Department located in the Central Maintenance Shop provides scheduled maintenance on Analyzers, DCS Control Equipment, Continuous Emission Monitors and various in-plant monitors. This

Department also provides instrument repair services in support of Instrument Field Maintenance.



Maintenance Staff



Maintenance Staff provides maintenance cost, performance and environmental reporting coordination and services for all Maintenance Departments and administrative support for entire Maintenance Department.



Maintenance Satellite Shops



The Maintenance Department has an established Satellite Shop at each operating plant. These satellite shops provide Mechanical, Electrical, and Instrument Maintenance Services to the Operating Units. The following descriptions apply to all three Maintenance Disciplines. Interactions with Operating Units are through established Equipment Route Checks, scheduled preventative maintenance, and analysis of abnormal equipment conditions. In addition to regularly scheduled maintenance activities, the Satellite shops meet weekly with Operations to discuss concerns, schedules, and abnormal analysis results. Various Maintenance services are also performed upon request from Operations through the work order system. This system allows requested work to be managed and completed in a timely manner.



The Maintenance Organization as a whole exists to support Operations and provide equipment reliability, efficiency, and therefo

re equipment safety. 



Formosa Plastics Corporation, Texas maintains continual improvement of our existing systems. Several planned enhancements include the addition of Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) for scenarios from our process hazard analysis with high severity/risk ranking. Additional analysis will be included, as required, in all future PHA revalidations as well as changes to any process that may prompt a new or revised PHA. We also plan to review and suggested improvements to the positive material identification (PMI) program to adjust to and incorporate changing industry standards and practices.
